segments.text: Hey. When you guys were kids and you played
segments.speaker: Ross

segments.text: I was always Joanne.
segments.speaker: Monica

segments.text: Question. Was ah, 'Egg the Gellers!' the war cry of your neighbourhood?
segments.speaker: Joey

segments.text: Ewww! Oh! It's the Mattress King!
segments.speaker: Phoebe

segments.text: Don't look honey. Change the channel! Change the channel!
segments.speaker: Chandler

segments.text: Wait! Wait! I wanna see this. After I divorce him, half of that kingdom is gonna be mine.
segments.speaker: Janice

segments.text: What a wank!
segments.speaker: Chandler

segments.text: Oh, I cannot believe he's using our divorce to sell mattresses.
segments.speaker: Janice

segments.text: I know!
segments.speaker: Monica

segments.text: And four ninety-nine for a pillow top queen set, who cares about the divorce, those babies will sell themselves.
segments.speaker: Monica

segments.text: And I'm appalled for you by the way.
segments.speaker: Monica

segments.text: You had to do it, didn't you? You couldn't just leave it alone.
segments.speaker: Rachel

segments.text: Four percent. Okay. I tip more than that when there's a bug in my food.
segments.speaker: Ross

segments.text: Ross, tonight was about the two of you getting along.  Oh, would you just see my chiropractor, already.
segments.speaker: Rachel

segments.text: Yeah, I'm gonna go to a doctor who went to school in a mini-mall.
segments.speaker: Ross

segments.text: Hey Pheebs, what are you doing?
segments.speaker: Ross

segments.text: I'm, I'm freaking out!
segments.speaker: Phoebe

segments.text: Monica kinda trusted me with something and she shouldn't have!
segments.speaker: Phoebe

segments.text: All right, I haven't lived here in a while, so I have to ask you something.
segments.speaker: Phoebe

segments.text: Does Monica still turn on the lights in her bedroom?
segments.speaker: Phoebe

segments.text: Um. yeah.
segments.speaker: Rachel

segments.text: I am
segments.speaker: Phoebe

segments.text: All right, look, here's the bottom line Ross, this is fixable, if we act fast, okay.
segments.speaker: Rachel

segments.text: So, I'll invite him to brunch tomorrow and you can make nice.
segments.speaker: Rachel

segments.text: Look, honey, I have tried to make nice, it doesn't work.
segments.speaker: Ross

segments.text: Okay, look, Ross, I realise that my Father is difficult, but that's why you have got to be the bigger man here.
segments.speaker: Rachel

segments.text: Look sweetie, I could be the bigger man, I could be the biggest man, I could be a big, huge, giant man, and it still wouldn't make any difference, except that I could pick your Father up and say 'Like me!
segments.speaker: Ross

segments.text: Like me tiny doctor!'
segments.speaker: Ross

segments.text: Okay, well can't you just try it one more time Ross? For me? For me?
segments.speaker: Rachel

segments.text: Rachel one brunch is not gonna solve anything. You gotta face it, okay we're never gonna get along.
segments.speaker: Ross

segments.text: Okay, well you are just gonna have too, okay.
segments.speaker: Rachel

segments.text: Because I already got a Mother and a Father who cannot stay in the same room together, okay, I don't wanna have to have a separate room for you too!
segments.speaker: Rachel

segments.text: Okay, okay, okay.  I'll get the bagels.
segments.speaker: Ross
